text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with barbecue shrimp that's right
I'm doing my take on this indigenous
American shellfish dish and while
usually I'm the one giving things the
wrong name this time it was the lovely
and talented people of New Orleans who
decided to call this barbecue shrimp
even though it really has nothing to do
with barbecue but what it does have
something to do with is being incredibly
delicious so here is what we're gonna do
we need about a pound and a half of what
they call colossal shrimp which is kind
of funny because as some of you found
out call me something that's only four
inches long colossal usually doesn't
work out but anyway that's the official
name for these because they come fifteen
to a pound and I'm also using ones that
are called easy peel which means they've
been split down the back which makes
removing the exoskeleton very simple so
the only places really attached is down
by the tail so I just take my
fingernails and peel that little piece
off I try to get all that tail meat out
intact and then once you peel that part
of the shell the rest will come right
off and not only are these easy peel
shrimp easier to peel they're also
devayne so very easy to work with
so bottom line you're going to peel and
devein your shrimp you're going to
separate the shells into a saucepan and
reserve those and of course the shrimp
you can throw right in a mixing bowl and
then what we're going to do is we're
going to take the shrimp and drizzle
over about a tablespoon and a half or so
of some kind of vegetable oil something
neutral and then we're going to season
this up and the first thing we're going
to add here is a ton of freshly and
coarsely ground black pepper I'm also
going to put in a little bit of paprika
I'm using smoked paprika a little shake
of cayenne and then last but not least a
little bit of Old Bay please do not
substitute with a young Bay and then
we're going to mix that up and when it's
tossed and combined thoroughly I'm gonna
throw a piece of plastic over that and
we're going to let that sit in the
fridge for at least an hour we want that
shrimp to start absorbing those flavors
so you can leave in the fridge for at
least an hour a couple hours is fine
I guess overnight would be okay although
I've never tried that and while that's
chilly we're going to go back over to
the stove and make a shrimp stock which
is so simple so how'd you put all your
shrimp shells in a saucepan and we're
going to place that over medium-high
heat with a little chunk of butter and
we're just going to saute that for a
minute or two until the shells turn a
pink and even more so than color you can
go by smell here when that smells like
awesome sauteed shrimp it's done so cook
it for a minute or two until it turns
pink and smells awesome
and then we're going to dump in about
two cups of liquid I'm using chicken
stock you can use
water but I do like the chicken stock if
I have it and then all we're going to do
is wait for that to come up to a simmer
turn it down to low and just let it
simmer on the back of the stove for
about 20 minutes okay and a little bit
will evaporate but that's fine and in
about 20 minutes or a half hour you
should have a very beautiful and fully
flavoured shrimp stock at that point
just go ahead and strain that into a
bowl and after that's been strained
we're going to go ahead and add the rest
of the wet ingredients which is the
juice of a lemon freshly squeezed of
course come on we're also going to need
some wishes your sauce and then a few
shakes of hot sauce anything from
Louisiana will work and then we're going
to mix that up and that's it and at this
point I believe all our components are
ready so here's what I'm thinking we're
going to take the shrimp and we're going
to sear those in a really really hot pan
at that point we're going to add a bunch
of butter some freshly chopped rosemary
and a ton of minced garlic we'll cook
that a little bit and then we'll finish
it with our shrimp stock mixture okay so
if everyone's good with that let's go
over to the stove where we placed our
largest frying pan on high high heat and
we need to preheat that like super super
hot this literally can't be too hot and
when you're sure it's been preheated
we're going to go ahead and place in the
shrimp no oil in it dry pan remember the
shrimp's coated in oil we don't need any
oil in this and we're just going to give
this first side one minute of serine and
if your pan was hot enough one minute is
all it should take to get a really
beautiful sear on that first side now
you can see here we're going to go ahead
and turn those over again the heats on
the highest it will go oh and by the way
this is why you want to use large shrimp
so you can get a really beautiful sear
on them before they overcook all right
so we're going to flip all those over
and as soon as those get turned we're
going to quickly throw in our butter
which you can see I've cut into small
chunks the toss and the butter toss and
the garlic toss in the rosemary and
we're just going to cook this for one
minute so take your tongs give it a stir
we do not want to Brown the garlic
all right slightly Golden's fine Brown
is not so one minute should be fine
the brownest you see at the bottom of
the pan is not the garlic that's the
carmelization from the shrimp so relax I
was fine and after a 1 minute stir in
sizzle we're going to quickly pour in
our shrimp stock which of course is
going to deglaze the pan
and this recipe is pretty much done now
what you can do is just let this boil
and reduce for a few minutes and serve
it but what I like to do is remove the
shrimp and reserve them and reduce the
sauce without the shrimp in it because
the fear is over cooking the shrimp
while you finish the sauce and by
removing it you don't worry about that
so I'm just going to scoop those out
onto a plate or in a bowl and then I'm
simply going to boil the sauce until
it's slightly thickens
of course the more you reduce it the
more intense the flavor gets alright the
spicier insult here it's going to be its
begin assault be careful seasoning that
wishes your sauce is salty in fact you
may want to put in the wishes here at
the end so you can kind of taste for the
salt but bottom line you're just trying
to reduce the sauce to thicken slightly
and then once that's happened and you've
tasted for seasoning reduce the heat to
low go ahead and dump your shrimp back
in give them a stir till they're warm
through which is just going to take a
minute and then spoon that up on some
rice and you are in store for one of the
great great American shellfish recipes
of all time I mean look at that barbecue
shrimp and because we used it in the
sauce that's completely legal to garnish
with a rosemary sprig just a gorgeous
looking and tasting dish and again this
is my version I believe the authentic
version has approximately 14 times more
butter but still this was incredibly
delicious and all those big flavors just
works so well together the garlic the
rosemary the black pepper the spice just
a beautiful combination and even the
plain rice with that sauce on it is
incredible and of course usually I say
serve this on whatever you want in this
case no no you're not the boss of your
barbecued shrimp basis you will serve

wrap things up here I'd say the two
secrets try to get the largest shrimp
you can get and take the couple extra
minutes to make that shrimp stock but
anyway if you're a fan of shrimp or just
